# United States Forces Japan

United States Forces Japan

---

The **United States Forces Japan** (**USFJ**) (在日米軍, __Zainichi Beigun__) is
an active subordinate unified command of the [United States Indo-Pacific
Command](/wiki/United_States_Indo-Pacific_Command "United States Indo-Pacific
Command") (USINDOPACOM). It was activated at [Fuchū Air
Station](/wiki/Fuch%C5%AB_Air_Base_\(Tokyo\) "Fuchū Air Base \(Tokyo\)"),
[Tokyo](/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo"), [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan") on 1 July 1957 to
replace the [Far East Command](/wiki/Far_East_Command_\(United_States\) "Far
East Command \(United States\)") (FEC). USFJ is commanded by the **Commander,
U.S. Forces, Japan** (**COMUSJAPAN**). COMUSJAPAN is also the Commander,
[Fifth Air Force](/wiki/Fifth_Air_Force "Fifth Air Force"). At present, USFJ
is headquartered at [Yokota Air Base](/wiki/Yokota_Air_Base "Yokota Air
Base"), Tokyo, Japan.

COMUSJAPAN, plans, directs and supervises the execution of missions and
responsibilities assigned by the **Commander, U.S. Indo-Pacific Command**
(**COMUSINDOPACOM**). He establishes and implements policies to accomplish the
mission of the [United States Armed Forces](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces
"United States Armed Forces") in Japan. He is responsible for developing plans
for the defense of Japan, and he must be prepared if contingencies arise, to
assume operational control of assigned and attached U.S. forces for the
execution of those plans.

COMUSJAPAN supports the [Security
Treaty](/wiki/Treaty_of_Mutual_Cooperation_and_Security_between_the_United_States_and_Japan
"Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security between the United States and
Japan") and administers the [Status of Forces
Agreement](/wiki/U.S.%E2%80%93Japan_Status_of_Forces_Agreement "U.S.–Japan
Status of Forces Agreement") (SOFA) between the United States and Japan. He is
responsible for coordinating various matters of interest with the service
commanders in Japan. These include matters affecting US-Japan relationships
among and between [Department of
Defense](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department
of Defense") (DOD) agencies; DOD agencies and the U.S. Ambassador to Japan;
and DOD agencies and the Government of Japan (GOJ).

Under the Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security between the United States
and Japan, the United States is obliged to protect Japan in close cooperation
with the [Japan Self-Defense Forces](/wiki/Japan_Self-Defense_Forces "Japan
Self-Defense Forces") for maritime defense, ballistic missile defense,
domestic air control, communications security ([COMSEC](/wiki/COMSEC
"COMSEC")) and disaster response operations.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Forces_Japan&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/JGSDF_soldiers_at_Camp_Kinser_11-28-07.jpg/230px-
JGSDF_soldiers_at_Camp_Kinser_11-28-07.jpg)](/wiki/File:JGSDF_soldiers_at_Camp_Kinser_11-28-07.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:JGSDF_soldiers_at_Camp_Kinser_11-28-07.jpg "Enlarge")

[JGSDF](/wiki/Japan_Ground_Self-Defense_Force "Japan Ground Self-Defense
Force") [soldiers](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") at [Camp Kinser](/wiki/Camp_Kinser
"Camp Kinser")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/US_Navy_110315-N-IC111-125_Chief_Naval_Air_Crewman_Steven_Sinclair_hands_bottled_water_to_a_Japanese_citizen.jpg/220px-
US_Navy_110315-N-IC111-125_Chief_Naval_Air_Crewman_Steven_Sinclair_hands_bottled_water_to_a_Japanese_citizen.jpg)](/wiki/File:US_Navy_110315-N-IC111-125_Chief_Naval_Air_Crewman_Steven_Sinclair_hands_bottled_water_to_a_Japanese_citizen.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:US_Navy_110315-N-IC111-125_Chief_Naval_Air_Crewman_Steven_Sinclair_hands_bottled_water_to_a_Japanese_citizen.jpg
"Enlarge")

United States Forces helped Japanese in [Operation
Tomodachi](/wiki/Operation_Tomodachi "Operation Tomodachi") following the
[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and
tsunami](/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami "2011 Tōhoku earthquake
and tsunami")

After the [Japanese surrender](/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan "Surrender of Japan")
in the [end of World War II in Asia](/wiki/End_of_World_War_II_in_Asia "End of
World War II in Asia"), the [United States Armed
Forces](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces") assumed
administrative authority in Japan. The [Japanese Imperial
Army](/wiki/Japanese_Imperial_Army "Japanese Imperial Army") and
[Navy](/wiki/Japanese_Imperial_Navy "Japanese Imperial Navy") were
decommissioned, and the U.S. Armed Forces took control of their [military
bases](/wiki/Military_bases "Military bases") until the new government could
be formed and positioned to reestablish authority. [Allied
forces](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") planned to
[demilitarize](/wiki/Demilitarisation "Demilitarisation") Japan, and new
government adopted the [Constitution of Japan](/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan
"Constitution of Japan") with [a no-armed-force
clause](/wiki/Article_9_of_the_Japanese_Constitution "Article 9 of the
Japanese Constitution") in 1947.

After the [Korean War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War") began in 1950, [Douglas
MacArthur](/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur "Douglas MacArthur"), the [Supreme
Commander for the Allied Powers](/wiki/Supreme_Commander_for_the_Allied_Powers
"Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers") in Japan and the Japanese
government established the paramilitary "[National Police
Reserve](/wiki/National_Police_Reserve "National Police Reserve")", which was
later developed into the [Japan Ground Self-Defense
Force](/wiki/Japan_Ground_Self-Defense_Force "Japan Ground Self-Defense
Force") (JGSDF).

In 1951, the [Treaty of San Francisco](/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Francisco "Treaty
of San Francisco") was signed by the allied countries and Japan, which
restored its formal sovereignty. At the same time, the U.S. and Japan signed
the [Japan-America Security
Alliance](/wiki/Security_Treaty_Between_the_United_States_and_Japan "Security
Treaty Between the United States and Japan"). By this treaty, USFJ is
responsible for the defense of Japan. As part of this agreement, the Japanese
government requested that the U.S. military bases remain in Japan, and agreed
to provide funds and various interests specified in the [Status of Forces
Agreement](/wiki/Status_of_forces_agreement "Status of forces agreement"). At
the expiration of the treaty, the United States and Japan signed the new
[Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security between the United States and
Japan](/wiki/Treaty_of_Mutual_Cooperation_and_Security_between_the_United_States_and_Japan
"Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security between the United States and
Japan"). The status of the United States Forces Japan was defined in the
[U.S.–Japan Status of Forces
Agreement](/wiki/U.S.%E2%80%93Japan_Status_of_Forces_Agreement "U.S.–Japan
Status of Forces Agreement"). This treaty is still in effect, and it forms the
basis of Japan's foreign policy.

In the [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War"), the US military bases
in Japan, especially those in [Okinawa Prefecture](/wiki/Okinawa_Prefecture
"Okinawa Prefecture"), were used as important strategic and logistic bases. In
1970, the [Koza riot](/wiki/Koza_riot "Koza riot") occurred against the US
military presence in Okinawa. The USAF [strategic
bombers](/wiki/Strategic_bomber "Strategic bomber") were deployed in the bases
in Okinawa, which was still administered by the U.S. government. Before the
1972 reversion of the island to Japanese administration, it has been
speculated but never confirmed that up to 1,200 nuclear weapons may have been
stored at [Kadena Air Base](/wiki/Kadena_Air_Base "Kadena Air Base"),
[Okinawa](/wiki/Okinawa_Prefecture "Okinawa Prefecture") in the 1960s.[1]

As of
2013[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States_Forces_Japan&action=edit),
there are approximately 50,000 U.S. military personnel stationed in Japan,
along with approximately 40,000 dependents of military personnel and another
5,500 American civilians employed there by the [United States Department of
Defense](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department
of Defense"). The [United States Seventh
Fleet](/wiki/United_States_Seventh_Fleet "United States Seventh Fleet") is
based in [Yokosuka](/wiki/Yokosuka,_Kanagawa "Yokosuka, Kanagawa"), [Kanagawa
Prefecture](/wiki/Kanagawa_Prefecture "Kanagawa Prefecture"). The [3rd Marine
Expeditionary Force](/wiki/3rd_Marine_Expeditionary_Force "3rd Marine
Expeditionary Force") (III MEF) is based in [Okinawa](/wiki/Okinawa_Prefecture
"Okinawa Prefecture"). 130 USAF fighters are stationed in the [Misawa Air
Base](/wiki/Misawa_Air_Base "Misawa Air Base") and [Kadena Air
Base](/wiki/Kadena_Air_Base "Kadena Air Base").[2]

The [Japanese government](/wiki/Government_of_Japan "Government of Japan")
paid [¥](/wiki/%C2%A5 "¥")217 billion (US$2.0 billion) in 2007[3] as annual
host-nation support called [Omoiyari Yosan](/wiki/Omoiyari_Yosan "Omoiyari
Yosan") (思いやり予算, sympathy budget or compassion budget).[4] As of the 2011
budget, such payment was no longer to be referred to as Omoiyari Yosan or
sympathy budget.[5] Japan compensates 75 percent of U.S. basing costs — $4.4
billion.[6]

The [U.S. government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal
government of the United States") employs over 8,000 Master Labor Contract
(MLC)/Indirect Hire Agreement (IHA) workers on Okinawa (per the Labor
Management Organization) not including Okinawan contract workers.[7]

Immediately after the [2011 Tōhoku earthquake and
tsunami](/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami "2011 Tōhoku earthquake
and tsunami"), 9,720 dependents of United States military and government
civilian employees in Japan evacuated the country, mainly to the United
States.[8]

The relocation of the U.S. [Marine Corps Air Station
Futenma](/wiki/Marine_Corps_Air_Station_Futenma "Marine Corps Air Station
Futenma") to [Henoko](/wiki/Henoko_Bay "Henoko Bay") had been resolved in
December 2013 with the signing of the landfill agreement by the governor of
Okinawa. Under the terms of the U.S.-Japan agreement 5,000 U.S. Marines should
have been relocated to [Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam") and 4,000 U.S. Marines to
other Pacific locations such as [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii") or
[Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"), while some 10,000 Marines were to
remain on [Okinawa](/wiki/Okinawa_Prefecture "Okinawa
Prefecture").[9][10][11][12][13][14][15] No timetable for the Marines
redeployment had been announced, but _[The Washington
Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")_ reported that U.S.
Marines would leave Okinawa as soon as suitable facilities on Guam and
elsewhere were ready.[12] The relocation move was expected to cost 8.6 billion
US Dollars[9] and includes a $3.1bn cash commitment from Japan for the move to
Guam as well as for developing joint training ranges on Guam and on
[Tinian](/wiki/Tinian "Tinian") and [Pagan](/wiki/Pagan_\(island\) "Pagan
\(island\)") in the [Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana
Islands](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_the_Northern_Mariana_Islands "Commonwealth of
the Northern Mariana Islands").[10] Certain parcels of land on Okinawa which
have been leased for use by the American military were supposed to be turned
back to Japanese control via a long-term phased return process according to
the agreement.[12] These returns have been ongoing since 1972.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
However, as of July 2016, the situation has not been settled.

Further information: [Relocation of Marine Corps Air Station
Futenma](/wiki/Relocation_of_Marine_Corps_Air_Station_Futenma "Relocation of
Marine Corps Air Station Futenma")

In May 2014, in a strategic shift by the United States to Asia and the
Pacific, it was revealed the US was deploying two unarmed [Global Hawk long-
distance surveillance drones](/wiki/Northrop_Grumman_RQ-4_Global_Hawk
"Northrop Grumman RQ-4 Global Hawk") to Japan for surveillance missions over
[China](/wiki/China "China") and [North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea "North
Korea").[16]

## U.S. presence
debate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Forces_Japan&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: U.S. presence debate")]

**Do they need bases in Henoko or Futenma? Are they unnecessary? Even aside
from this discussion, security is changing.** — _Former Japan[Minister of
Defense](/wiki/Minister_of_Defense "Minister of Defense") [Fumio
Kyuma](/wiki/Fumio_Kyuma "Fumio Kyuma")_[17]

### U.S. presence on
Okinawa[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Forces_Japan&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: U.S. presence on Okinawa")]

See also: [Okinawa Prefecture § U.S. military
controversy](/wiki/Okinawa_Prefecture#U.S._military_controversy "Okinawa
Prefecture")

Okinawa makes up only 0.6 percent of the nation's land area;[2] yet,
approximately 62% of U.S. bases in Japan (exclusive use only) are in
Okinawa.[18][19]

### Survey among Japanese and
Okinawans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Forces_Japan&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Survey among Japanese and Okinawans")]

While, in 2002, 73.4% of Japanese citizens appreciate the mutual security
treaty with the U.S. and the presence of the USFJ,[20][_[needs
update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] part of the population
demands a reduction in the number of U.S. military bases in Okinawa.[21]

In May 2010, a survey of the Okinawan people conducted by the _[Mainichi
Shimbun](/wiki/Mainichi_Shimbun "Mainichi Shimbun")_ and the _[Ryūkyū
Shimpō](/wiki/Ry%C5%ABky%C5%AB_Shimp%C5%8D "Ryūkyū Shimpō")_ , found that 71%
of Okinawans surveyed thought that the presence of Marines on Okinawa was not
necessary (15% said it was necessary.). Asked what they thought about 62% of
United States Forces Japan bases (exclusive use) being concentrated in
Okinawa, 50% said that the number should be reduced, 41% said that the bases
should be removed. Asked about the US-Japan security treaty, 55% said it
should be changed to a peace treaty, 14% said it should be abolished and 7%
said it should be maintained.[22]

Many of the bases, such as [Yokota Air Base](/wiki/Yokota_Air_Base "Yokota Air
Base"), [Naval Air Facility Atsugi](/wiki/Naval_Air_Facility_Atsugi "Naval Air
Facility Atsugi") and [Kadena Air Base](/wiki/Kadena_Air_Base "Kadena Air
Base"), are located in the vicinity of residential districts, and local
citizens have complained about excessive aircraft noise.[23][24][25] The 2014
poll by _Ryūkyū Shimpō_ found that 80% of surveyed Okinawans want the [Marine
Corps Air Station Futenma](/wiki/Marine_Corps_Air_Station_Futenma "Marine
Corps Air Station Futenma") moved out of the prefecture.[26]

On 25 June 2018 residents of the island of Okinawa have rallied against the
construction of a new airfield intended for the US military base in the United
States. The activists, armed with placards and banners, went to sea on seventy
boats and ships. The posters read: “Do not build a base” and “Stop throwing
gravel”. Protesters urged the Japanese authorities to stop the expansion of
the US military presence on the island. Some of the boats went to the guarded
construction site, where they came across the Coast Guard patrol vessels. Some
activists were arrested for invading a prohibited zone.[27]

### Status of forces
agreement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Forces_Japan&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Status of forces agreement")]

There is also debate over the [Status of Forces
Agreement](/wiki/Status_of_forces_agreement "Status of forces agreement") due
to the fact that it covers a variety of administrative technicalities blending
the systems which control how certain situations are handled between the
U.S.'s and Japan's legal framework.[28]

### U.S. service member
behavior[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Forces_Japan&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: U.S. service member behavior")]

Between 1972 and 2009, U.S. servicemen committed 5,634 criminal offenses,
including 25 murders, 385 burglaries, 25 arsons, 127 rapes, 306 assaults and
2,827 thefts.[29] Yet, per [Marine Corps Installations
Pacific](/wiki/Marine_Corps_Installations_Pacific "Marine Corps Installations
Pacific") data, U.S. service members are convicted of far fewer crimes than
local Okinawans.[30] According to the [U.S.-Japan Status of Forces
Agreement](/wiki/U.S.-Japan_Status_of_Forces_Agreement "U.S.-Japan Status of
Forces Agreement"), when U.S. personnel crimes are committed both off-duty and
off-base, they should always be prosecuted under the Japanese law.[31]

On 12 February 2008, the National Police Agency (of Japan) or NPA, released
its annual criminal statistics that included activity within the Okinawan
prefecture. These findings held American troops were only convicted of 53
crimes per 10,000 U.S. male servicemen, while Okinawan males were convicted of
366 crimes per 10,000. The crime rate found a U.S. serviceman in Okinawa to be
86% less likely to convicted of a crime by the Japanese government than an
Okinawan male.[32]

### Crime
issues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Forces_Japan&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Crime issues")]

See also: [Yumiko-chan incident](/wiki/Yumiko-chan_incident "Yumiko-chan
incident"), [1995 Okinawa rape incident](/wiki/1995_Okinawa_rape_incident
"1995 Okinawa rape incident"), and [Michael Brown Okinawa assault
incident](/wiki/Michael_Brown_Okinawa_assault_incident "Michael Brown Okinawa
assault incident")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Yasuura_House.jpg/220px-
Yasuura_House.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yasuura_House.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Yasuura_House.jpg "Enlarge")

GIs in [Special Comfort Facility
Association](/wiki/Special_Comfort_Facility_Association "Special Comfort
Facility Association") during [occupation of Japan](/wiki/Occupation_of_Japan
"Occupation of Japan").

At the beginning of the [occupation of Japan](/wiki/Occupation_of_Japan
"Occupation of Japan"), in 1945, many U.S. soldiers participated in the
[Special Comfort Facility
Association](/wiki/Special_Comfort_Facility_Association "Special Comfort
Facility Association").[33] The Japanese government recruited 55,000 women to
work providing sexual services to US military personnel.[33] The Association
was closed by the [Supreme Commander for the Allied
Powers](/wiki/Supreme_Commander_for_the_Allied_Powers "Supreme Commander for
the Allied Powers").[33]

In more recent history, "crimes ranging from rape to assault and hit-and-run
accidents by U.S. military personnel, dependents and civilians have long
sparked protests in the prefecture," stated _[The Japan
Times](/wiki/The_Japan_Times "The Japan Times")_.[34] "A series of horrific
crimes by present and former U.S. military personnel stationed on Okinawa has
triggered dramatic moves to try to reduce the American presence on the island
and in Japan as a whole," commented _[The Daily Beast](/wiki/The_Daily_Beast
"The Daily Beast")_ in 2009.[35]

In 1995, the [abduction and rape of a 12-year-old Okinawan
schoolgirl](/wiki/1995_Okinawa_rape_incident "1995 Okinawa rape incident") by
two U.S. marines and one U.S. sailor led to demands for the removal of all
U.S. military bases in Japan. Other controversial incidents include helicopter
crashes, the [Girard incident](/wiki/Girard_incident "Girard incident"), the
[Michael Brown Okinawa assault
incident](/wiki/Michael_Brown_Okinawa_assault_incident "Michael Brown Okinawa
assault incident"), the death of [Kinjo
family](/wiki/1996_Padilla_car_accident "1996 Padilla car accident") and the
death of [Yuki Uema](/wiki/Randall_Eskridge "Randall Eskridge"). In February
2008, a 38-year-old U.S. Marine based on Okinawa was arrested in connection
with the reported rape of a 14-year-old Okinawan girl.[36] This triggered
waves of protest against American military presence in Okinawa and led to
tight restrictions on off-base activities.[37][38] Although the accuser
withdrew her charges the U.S. military court-martialed the suspect and
sentenced him to 4 years in prison under the stricter rules of the military
justice system.[39]

U.S. Forces Japan designated 22 February as a _Day of Reflection_ for all U.S.
military facilities in Japan, and established the Sexual Assault Prevention
and Response Task Force in an effort to prevent similar incidents.[40] In
November 2009, Staff Sgt. Clyde "Drew" Gunn, a U.S. Army soldier stationed at
Torii Station was involved in a hit-and-run accident of a pedestrian in
Yomitan Village on Okinawa. Later, in April 2010, the soldier was charged with
failing to render aid and vehicular manslaughter.[41] Staff Sgt. Gunn, of
Ocean Springs, Mississippi, was eventually sentenced to 2 years and 8 months
in jail on 15 October 2010.[42]

In 2013, two U.S. military personnel, Seaman Christopher Browning, of [Athens,
Texas](/wiki/Athens,_Texas "Athens, Texas"), and Petty Officer 3rd Class
Skyler Dozierwalker, of [Muskogee, Oklahoma](/wiki/Muskogee,_Oklahoma
"Muskogee, Oklahoma"), were found guilty by the Naha District Court of raping
and robbing a woman in her 20s in a parking lot in October. Both admitted
committing the crime. The case outraged many Okinawans, a number of whom have
long complained of military-related crime on their island, which hosts
thousands of U.S. troops. It also sparked tougher restrictions for all 50,000
U.S. military personnel in Japan, including a curfew and drinking
restrictions.[43]

On 13 May 2013, in a very controversial statement, [Toru
Hashimoto](/wiki/Toru_Hashimoto "Toru Hashimoto"), co-leader of the [Japan
Restoration Association](/wiki/Japan_Restoration_Association "Japan
Restoration Association") said to a senior American military official at the
Marine Corps base in Okinawa "We can’t control the sexual energy of these
brave marines." and told United States soldiers should make more use of the
[local adult entertainment industry](/wiki/Prostitution_in_Japan "Prostitution
in Japan") to reduce [sexual crimes](/wiki/Sexual_crime "Sexual crime")
against local women.[44] Hashimoto also told the necessity of former Japanese
Army [comfort women](/wiki/Comfort_women "Comfort women") and of prostitutes
for the US military in other countries [such as Korea](/wiki/Western_princess
"Western princess").[44]

In June 2016, after a civilian worker at the base was charged with murdering a
Japanese woman, tens of thousands of people protested in Okinawa.[45]
Organizers estimated turnout at 65,000 people, which would be the largest
anti-base protests in Okinawa since 1995.[46]

In November 2017, an intoxicated US service member was arrested following a
vehicle crash on the Japanese island of Okinawa that killed the other
driver.[47]

### Osprey deployment in
Okinawa[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Forces_Japan&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Osprey deployment in Okinawa")]

In October 2012, twelve [MV-22 Ospreys](/wiki/Bell_Boeing_V-22_Osprey "Bell
Boeing V-22 Osprey") were transferred to the US Marine Corps Air Station
Futenma to replace aging Vietnam-era [Boeing Vertol CH-46 Sea
Knight](/wiki/Boeing_Vertol_CH-46_Sea_Knight "Boeing Vertol CH-46 Sea Knight")
helicopters in Okinawa.[48] In October 2013, an additional 12 Ospreys arrived,
again to replace CH-46 Sea Knights, increasing the number of Ospreys to 24.
Japanese Defence Minister [Satoshi Morimoto](/wiki/Satoshi_Morimoto "Satoshi
Morimoto") explained the Osprey aircraft is safe adding that two recent
accidents were 'caused by human factors'.[49] Japanese Prime Minister
[Yoshihiko Noda](/wiki/Yoshihiko_Noda "Yoshihiko Noda") also stated that the
Japanese government was convinced of the MV-22's safety.[50] Various incidents
involving V-22 Ospreys have occurred in Okinawa.[51] On 5 April, 2018, it was
announced that the US Air Force is to officially deploy CV-22 Osprey aircraft
at its Yokota Air Base on the outskirts of Tokyo in a few months. The
deployment would be the first of Ospreys in Japan other than in Okinawa, where
the US Marines have already deployed their version of the aircraft, known as
the MV-22s.[52]

On 25 April, 2018 two US Air Force Osprey MV-22, deployed at US Marine Corps
Air Station Futenma on the Okinawa island, made an emergency landing at the
Amami Airport on the nearby island in Kagoshima Prefecture. US Ospreys have
experienced numerous mishaps in recent years, prompting Japanese officials to
call for revision of certain provisions of the US-Japan Status of Forces
Agreement (SOFA), which outlines the rights and privileges of foreign military
personnel present in the country.
[[5]](https://sputniknews.com/asia/201804251063897210-osprey-japan-emergency-
landing-japan/)

##

Air Base"), about 30 km west of central Tokyo.

In Okinawa, U.S. military installations occupy about 10.4 percent of the total
land usage. Approximately 74.7 percent of all the U.S. military facilities in
Japan are located on the island of Okinawa.

### List of former
facilities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Forces_Japan&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: List of former facilities")]

The United States has returned some facilities to Japanese control. Some are
used as military bases of the JSDF; others have become civilian airports or
government offices; many are factories, office buildings or residential
developments in the private sector. Due to the [Special Actions Committee on
Okinawa](/wiki/Special_actions_committee_on_Okinawa "Special actions committee
on Okinawa"), more land in Okinawa is in the process of being returned. These
areas include—Camp Kuwae [also known as Camp Lester], MCAS Futenma, areas
within Camp Zukeran [also known as Camp Foster], about 9,900 acres (40 km2) of
the Northern Training Area, Aha Training Area, Gimbaru Training Area (also
known as Camp Gonsalves), small portion of the Makiminato Service Area (also
known as Camp Kinser), and Naha Port.
